Line 10: Line 10:      
[[Humanistic psychology]] sets healthy [[self-esteem]], understood as unconditional self-respect and self-confidence (and interpretable in certain context as self-love), as an essential requirement for every healthy interpersonal relation, including interpersonal love.<ref>Nathaniel Branden. ''The psychology of self-esteem: a new concept of man's psychological nature''. 1981.</ref>
 
[[Humanistic psychology]] sets healthy [[self-esteem]], understood as unconditional self-respect and self-confidence (and interpretable in certain context as self-love), as an essential requirement for every healthy interpersonal relation, including interpersonal love.<ref>Nathaniel Branden. ''The psychology of self-esteem: a new concept of man's psychological nature''. 1981.</ref>
  +   +
[[Buddhism]] sets attachment as a negative emotion that releases other negative emotions like anger and desire. In the buddhist philosophy, true love is compassionate love.<ref name="Buddha">[http://books.google.es/books?id=VECepVHTH0QC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false Guatama Buddha. ''The Dhammapada''. Translated by Irving Babbitt.]</ref> This concept is diametrically opposed to the concept of capitalism, which promotes the so called inherent selfishness of the human being.
     
<!-- themes -->Love in its various forms acts as a major facilitator of [[interpersonal relationship]]s and, owing to its central psychological importance, is one of the most common themes in the [[creative arts]].
 
<!-- themes -->Love in its various forms acts as a major facilitator of [[interpersonal relationship]]s and, owing to its central psychological importance, is one of the most common themes in the [[creative arts]].
